quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 9 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 9.7: Product-to-Sum Formulas
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Converting trig products into sums or differences

questions.question: Which formula is used to rewrite $\cos u \cos v$?
questions.explanation: The product of two cosines results in the sum of two cosines.

questions.question: In the formula for $\sin u \sin v$, which term comes first inside the brackets?
questions.explanation: Unlike the others, $\sin u \sin v$ uses $\cos(u - v) - \cos(u + v)$.

questions.question: If $u = v$, the formula for $\cos u \cos v$ simplifies to which identity?
questions.explanation: If $u=v$, you get $1/2 [\cos(2u) + \cos(0)] = 1/2 [\cos(2u) + 1]$, which is the power-reducing formula for $\cos^2 u$.

questions.question: Simplify: $2 \cos(45^\circ) \cos(15^\circ)$ using product-to-sum.
questions.explanation: The '$2$' in front cancels the '$1/2$' in the formula, leaving $\cos(45+15) + \cos(45-15)$.

questions.question: What is the result of $\cos(x) \sin(y)$ when using the formula?
questions.explanation: This is the 'Cosine × Sine' formula, which uses the difference of two sines.

questions.question: True or False: The product-to-sum formulas are derived from the sum and difference identities.
questions.explanation: True. For example, adding $\cos(u+v)$ and $\cos(u-v)$ causes the sine terms to cancel, leaving only the cosine product.

questions.question: Rewrite $4 \sin x \sin 2x$ as a difference of cosines.
Which of these expressions is equivalent to $\frac{\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)}{2}$?
questions.explanation: This is simply the $\sin u \cos v$ product-to-sum formula rearranged.

questions.question: Why does $\cos(-x)$ become $\cos(x)$ in these formula applications?
options: Because cosine is an even function.
Because cosine is an odd function.
Because the angle is in Quadrant I.
It doesn't; it should stay negative.
questions.explanation: Since $\cos(-x) = \cos(x)$, we always simplify the 'u-v' term if it results in a negative value.

scoreMessages.90: Product-to-Sum Powerhouse! You've mastered the tricky ones.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Just watch out for that $\sin u \sin v$ formula—it's the rebel of the group.
scoreMessages.50: Keep a list of these formulas handy while you practice; they are hard to memorize!
scoreMessages.0: Review the four main product-to-sum conversion patterns.
